fields.summary: Twitter Sets Policy for Handling Premature Claims of Election Victory
fields.details: Twitter implemented a policy for handling premature claims of election victories. To recognize results, the platform requires either an official announcement from state election authorities or a projection from at least two authoritative, national news outlets. Tweets with premature victory claims will be labeled and direct users to Twitter’s official US election page.

fields.summary: Elon Musk Acquires Twitter
fields.details: Elon Musk completed his acquisition of Twitter on October 27, 2022, in a deal valued at approximately $44 billion. Following the acquisition, Musk immediately took control of the company, dissolving the board of directors and naming himself CEO.

fields.summary: Meta Announces Termination of CrowdTangle Data Tool for Researchers
fields.details: Meta announced that CrowdTangle, a data transparency tool for external researchers, will no longer be available after August 14, 2024. In their announcement, Meta stated that new research tools, Meta Content Library and Content Library API, will provide useful, high-quality data to researchers as replacements for CrowdTangle.

fields.summary: Meta Stops Recommending Political Content on Instagram and Threads
fields.details: Meta adjusted its recommendation system to no longer suggest political content on Instagram and Threads. Users can still see political content from accounts they actively follow. Critics raised concerns about the criteria used to define "political" content, arguing that this change limits a vital avenue for voter education. According to Meta's blog post, political content is defined as content "potentially related to things like laws, elections, or social topics."

fields.summary: Musk Grants "General Amnesty" to Suspended Accounts
fields.details: Elon Musk announced a "general amnesty" for suspended Twitter accounts following a user poll on the topic. The amnesty led to the reinstatement of users previously banned for offenses including violent threats, harassment, and spreading misinformation.

fields.summary: Facebook Follows Google's Lead, Announcing No Political Ads for One Week After the Election
fields.details: Facebook announced that it will not run political ads for one week following the 2020 election. This decision aligns with a similar move by Google, aiming to limit the spread of misinformation and prevent potential voter manipulation during the post-election period.

fields.summary: X Reports Trust and Safety Staffing Numbers to Senate Judiciary Committee
fields.details: In written disclosures to the Senate Judiciary Committee, X reported that it had 3,317 Trust and Safety employees and contractors in May 2022. By May 2023, this number had decreased to 2,849, reflecting a reduction in staffing over the course of a year.

fields.summary: Identity Verification Expanded to All Advertisers on YouTube
fields.details: YouTube has expanded its identity verification requirements to include all advertisers, not just those in political categories. Advertisers must now submit personal identification, business incorporation documents, or other information to verify their identity and the country in which they operate.

fields.summary: Launch of Twitter's Ads Transparency Center
fields.details: "You should be able to search for any Twitter handle and bring up all the ad campaigns from that account that have run for the past seven days. For political advertisers in the U.S., there will be additional data, including information around billing, ad spend, impressions per tweet and demographic targeting."

fields.summary: TikTok Responds to Stolen Election Conspiracies by Applying 'Banned Hashtags' Policy
fields.details: TikTok addressed the spread of stolen election conspiracies by enforcing its existing 'banned hashtags' policy on related hashtags. However, enforcement was inconsistent, with some hashtags being removed while others remained active.

fields.summary: Gab Employs Minimal Content Moderation, Users Manage Their Own Feeds
fields.details: Gab adopts a hands-off approach to content moderation, asserting that users are responsible for managing their own feeds using mute or block options. Users can report direct threats, pornography, doxxing, fedposting, site abuse, spam, and illegal posts. Each channel on Gab is moderated by volunteer admins who enforce channel-specific guidelines. Gab states it will remove illegal content and cooperate with authorities but emphasizes its role as a free speech platform.

fields.summary: Mozilla Foundation Releases Report on Platform Ad Transparency Tools, Finds All Lacking for External Researchers to Study Impact on European Elections
fields.details: The Mozilla Foundation study covers 11 platforms: AliExpress, Apple App Store, Bing, Booking.com, Alphabet’s Google Search & YouTube, LinkedIn, Meta, Pinterest, Snapchat, TikTok, X, and Zalando. The report concluded that none of these platforms provide fully functional ad repositories or the necessary tools and data for researchers and civil society groups to effectively monitor the impact of very large online platform (VLOP) advertisements on Europe’s upcoming elections.

fields.summary: Google Requires Disclosures for AI-Generated Content in Election Ads
fields.details: Google announced a new policy requiring all election advertisers to include a disclosure when their ads contain AI-generated content. This policy applies across all Google platforms. content.

fields.summary: Meta Launches Treads
fields.details: Meta has launched Threads, a new app designed for text sharing. The app aims to provide users with a platform for real-time conversations and updates, integrating with Instagram to allow seamless sharing and interaction across both platforms. Threads is positioned as a competitor to other text-based social media platforms, offering features that cater to public discussions and private conversations.

fields.summary: Changes to Recommendation System Concerning "Borderline" Content and Compliance with Community Standards
fields.details: Since January 2019, YouTube implemented over 30 changes to reduce the recommendation of "borderline" content and harmful misinformation.

fields.summary: X Cuts Half of Election Integrity Team, Including Leadership
fields.details: After previously promising to expand the Election Integrity team, X, under Elon Musk's leadership, cuts half of the team, including its leaders.

fields.summary: Labels Added to Twitter Posts Claiming Premature Electoral Victory
fields.details: Facebook and Twitter introduced a warning label for posts that claim a premature victory in the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election. The label reads: "Votes are being counted. The winner of the 2020 US Presidential Election has not been projected. See Election updates."

fields.summary: Musk Announces Formation of Content Moderation Council
fields.details: Elon Musk announced that Twitter would form a content moderation council with diverse viewpoints but did not provide timeline or specifics for delivery.

fields.summary: European Commission VP Věra Jourová Criticizes X for High Ratio of Disinformation Posts
fields.details: European Commission Vice President Věra Jourová, responsible for EU digital affairs and democracy, stated that "X, former Twitter — who is not under the Code anymore — is the platform with the largest ratio of mis- or disinformation posts." The remarks were made in the context of a report from the Code of Practice on Disinformation. Twitter had previously been part of the Code but withdrew under Elon Musk's leadership.

fields.summary: Google Requires AI Content Disclosure for All Election Ads
fields.details: Google announced that all election-related ads across its platforms must include a disclosure if they contain synthetic content that inauthentically depicts real or realistic-looking people or events.

fields.summary: External Study finds TikTok Fails to Detect Political Ads Containing Election Misinformation
fields.details: An external study by Global Witness found that TikTok, despite its ban on political ads, approved 90% of ads containing false and misleading election information. The researchers behind the study noted that they did not declare the ads as political and did not go through an identity verification process, yet the ads still violated TikTok’s election ad policies.

fields.summary: TikTok Bans Political Ads While Allowing Paid Ads
fields.details: TikTok announced that while paid advertisements are allowed on the platform, political ads are prohibited. The platform specified that political ads, including those promoting or opposing a candidate, current leader, political party, group, or issue at the federal, state, or local levels, do not align with the TikTok experience. This ban also includes election-related, advocacy, and issue-based ads.

fields.summary: YouTube Launches Media Literacy Campaign
fields.details: YouTube introduced an educational campaign aimed at improving media literacy by providing tips on recognizing manipulation tactics used to spread misinformation. The campaign addresses techniques such as using emotional language and cherry-picking information. Initially, the campaign will launch in the U.S., with plans to expand to other countries over time.

fields.summary: Twitter’s New Head of Trust & Safety Describes Shift Toward Automated Content Moderation
fields.details: Twitter’s new Head of Trust & Safety said that under Elon Musk's leadership, the platform is increasingly relying on automated systems to moderate content. This shift includes reducing manual content reviews and focusing on restricting the distribution of certain content rather than removing it entirely.

fields.summary: Twitter Relaunches Twitter Blue Verification with New Safety Checks and Account Labels
fields.details: Twitter reintroduced its Twitter Blue verification scheme, adding safety measures to prevent impersonation. The update replaced labels with checkmarks: grey for government accounts and blue for select businesses.

fields.summary: TikTok Announces Updates on Countering Influence Attempts, Including Expanded Policies for State-Affiliated Media and a New Transparency Report
fields.details: TikTok expanded its policies for state-affiliated media, now labeling content from such accounts and preventing their recommendation if they attempt to reach audiences outside their home country on global affairs. These accounts are also restricted from advertising outside their home country. Additionally, TikTok will share regular updates on covert influence operations, having disrupted 15 such operations, including some related to elections, from January to April 2024.

fields.summary: Discord Provides Trust and Safety Staffing Numbers to Senate Judiciary Committee
fields.details: In written disclosures to the Senate Judiciary Committee, Discord revealed that its trust and safety team had grown from 22 full-time employees in 2019 to 90 employees by 2023. However, after a round of layoffs in 2024, the team was reduced to 74 full-time employees, bringing it back to a size similar to its pre-2021 numbers.

fields.summary: Twitter Trust and Safety Lead Yoel Roth Resigns
fields.details: Yoel Roth, Twitter's Head of Trust and Safety, resigned in November 2022. In an op-ed published a week later, Roth emphasized the challenges of maintaining principled content moderation under Elon Musk's leadership, stating that a platform "whose policies are defined by edict has little need for a trust and safety function dedicated to its principled development."

fields.summary: WSJ Reports Threads Not Labeling State-Run Accounts from China, Russia
fields.details: The Wall Street Journal reports that Meta's Threads is not labeling state-run accounts, a practice that is standard on Instagram and Facebook. Meta launched Threads before fully building out the service to capitalize on Twitter’s struggles under Musk, resulting in the absence of basic moderation features, including labels for state-run accounts.

fields.summary: Election Misinformation Labels Largely Absent on Facebook Ahead of 2022 Election
fields.details: In the lead-up to the 2022 election, The Washington Post and Pro Publica analyzed candidate posts on Facebook that claimed the election was rigged or fraudulent. The analysis found that these posts were rarely labeled as misinformation despite the platforms' policies on misinformation.

fields.summary: Facebook Introduces Ban on Paid Ads that Discourage Voting
fields.details: Facebook implemented a ban on paid advertisements that suggest voting is useless or that advise people not to vote. This policy shift followed a recommendation from a civil rights audit, aimed at combating voter suppression and misinformation during the election process.

fields.summary: Twitter Fires Top Officials, Including Head of Legal Policy, Trust, and Safety Vijaya Gadde
fields.details: Twitter fired several top officials, including Vijaya Gadde, the head of legal policy, trust, and safety. Gadde was responsible for the decision to suspend President Trump's account. Elon Musk had criticized Gadde, calling her Twitter's "chief censor."

fields.summary: Senate Committee Reports Meta Laid Off 80% of Staff Working on Election Issues
fields.details: A letter from the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration states that Meta has reduced its election-related staff from 300 to 60 employees, representing an 80% decrease. Further layoffs are also planned.

fields.summary: Meta Staff Cuts Amount to a Quarter of Its Workforce
fields.details: Meta has made substantial staff reductions, cutting nearly a quarter of its workforce, which initially numbered around 87,000 in 2022. The company announced 11,000 layoffs in November 2022 and a further 10,000 in March 2023.

fields.summary: Twitter Rules Ban Content on Misinformation, Suppression, and False Affiliation
fields.details: Twitter enforces rules banning content in the following categories: 1) misinformation on how to participate in the civil process, 2) suppression and intimidation, and 3) false or misleading affiliation. Tweets violating these policies have reduced visibility (de-amplified) and may receive labels, but are not removed from the platform.

fields.summary: Facebook Voting Information Center Launches
fields.details: Facebook's new Voting Information Center provides authoritative information about voter eligibility, absentee ballot requests, in-person voting, and deadlines. The goal is to register 4 million voters, doubling the target from 2 million in 2016 and 2018. A link to register to vote is prominently displayed at the top of the page for all users aged 18 and older.

fields.summary: Twitter Updates Rules and Detection Efforts Regarding Election Integrity
fields.details: Twitter updated its rules to address fake accounts and misleading activities, focusing on removing accounts involved in malicious behaviors and coordinated inauthentic actions. The platform also targets the distribution of hacked materials and threats related to hacking. Detection efforts have led to a decrease in spam-related reports, and new measures include stricter developer registration and improved ban evasion systems. Product updates include a reverse-chronological timeline option and election labels for candidates. Twitter is also supporting voter registration through hashtags and custom emojis.

fields.summary: X Rolls Out Community Notes to Images Amidst Concerns About Deepfakes
fields.details: X has expanded its Community Notes feature, a crowdsourced moderation tool, to include images. This update comes as concerns about the spread of deepfake images rise. The new feature aims to help users identify misleading or manipulated images by allowing the community to add context and annotations.

fields.summary: TikTok Revises Synthetic Media Policies, Adds Disclosure Requirements
fields.details: TikTok’s updated policy prohibits synthetic media containing the likeness of any real private figure. While public figures have more latitude, TikTok restricts their use to prevent abuse and misleading content on political or financial issues. TikTok also disallows synthetic media of public figures for endorsements or any content violating other policies. To support disclosure, TikTok introduced new labels and began testing an "AI-generated" label, which it plans to apply automatically to content detected as AI-edited or AI-created.

fields.summary: Twitter Announces Certification and Disclosure Processes for Political Ads
fields.details: Following its decision to allow political ads, Twitter announced two new processes: a certification process for ad sponsors and a disclosure process for political ads. The specifics of the certification process are not publicly available. Users can request a disclosure report online to access details about political ads running on the platform, placing the burden on the public to seek this information rather than Twitter providing proactive disclosure.

fields.summary: Meta Introduces AI-Generated Content Labels on Facebook, Instagram, and Threads
fields.details: Meta announced that Facebook, Instagram, and Threads will use common technical standards to identify and label AI-generated photos and videos. This initiative complements a previous decision to label content generated with Meta's AI tools. The labels will include visible markers on the images, as well as invisible watermarks and metadata embedded within the image files. Meta acknowledges that it is currently not possible to identify all AI-generated content, and there are methods to remove invisible markers.

fields.summary: Facebook Announces It Will Label State-Controlled Media in Page and Ad Library
fields.details: Facebook will now label state-controlled media in both the Page and Ad Library. This initiative is designed to help users identify media organizations that are influenced or backed by governments.

fields.summary: WhatsApp Uses Tools and User Reports for Content Moderation, Guidelines Do Not Address Misinformation or Elections Specifically
fields.details: WhatsApp utilizes automated tools, manual review, and user reports to detect abuse. Users are encouraged to report posts that violate guidelines, which are reviewed by contract workers according to ProPublica. The guidelines prohibit sharing illegal content, incitement to violence, fraud, and content that causes serious harm, such as threats or exploitation.

fields.summary: Facebook Considered Banning Political Advertising, Shelved Plan in 2022
fields.details: Facebook explored banning political advertising starting in summer 2021 but abandoned the idea by summer 2022. The decision came amid concerns about the impact of Elon Musk's approach to free speech on Twitter.

fields.summary: External Study Finds Facebook Partially Effective in Detecting Election Misinformation in Political Ads
fields.details: In an external study by Global Witness revealed that Facebook was only partially successful in detecting and removing election misinformation in political ads. To run the study esearchers bypassed identity verification and did not declare the ads as political, yet these ads still breached Facebook's election ad policies.

fields.summary: External Study Finds that YouTube Successfully Detects and Removes Misinformation in Political Ads
fields.details: In an external study including TikTok and Facebook, which failed to regulalry successfuly detect misinformation in political ads, YouTube succeeded in both detecting election misinformation in political ads and suspending the channels responsible. The Global Witness study highlighted YouTube’s more effective response, even though the researchers did not declare the ads as political or go through identity verification.

fields.summary: YouTube Changes Policy to Allow Content Concerning the Big Steal
fields.details: YouTube will no longer remove content that advances false claims of widespread fraud, errors, or glitches in the 2020 and other past US Presidential elections, effective June 2, 2023.

fields.summary: Twitter Removes All State Media Labels
fields.details: Twitter removed state media labels from all accounts, including outlets such as BBC, NPR, and other publicly funded media. This decision followed backlash against the labeling, now allowing content from state-affiliated media, including those from China and Russia, to circulate without designation.

fields.summary: Twitter to Remove Tweets Encouraging Violence or Interference with Election Results and Polling Places
fields.details: Twitter announced a policy update stating that tweets encouraging violence, or calling for interference with election results or the smooth operation of polling places, will be removed. This measure aims to ensure the integrity and safety of the election process.

fields.summary: Twitter Launches 2020 Election Hub at Top of Explore Tab
fields.details: The 2020 Election Hub includes English and Spanish language election news presented as Twitter Moments created by reputable news outlets, livestreams of debates and other election events, and voter education PSAs.

fields.summary: Google Updates its Political Content Policy to Require Disclosure from Ads Using Synthetic Content.
fields.details: Google's updated policy says that political ads containing synthetic content must include a disclosure. However, ads with synthetic alterations that do not significantly affect the ad's claims, such as image resizing, cropping, color corrections, defect removal (e.g., “red eye” removal), or minor background edits, are exempt from this requirement.

fields.summary: TikTok Updates Community Guidelines to Prohibit Synthetic or Manipulated Content
fields.details: TikTok has updated its community guidelines to explicitly prohibit synthetic or manipulated content that misleads users by distorting the truth of events, particularly when such distortion could cause harm. The update aims to enhance protection against shallow and deep fakes, making the policy clearer and more targeted for users.

fields.summary: Musical.ly and TikTok Merge, Bringing TikTok to the U.S.
fields.details: TikTok and Musical.ly announced their merger, leading to TikTok's expansion into the U.S. market. This move combined the user bases of both apps, integrating Musical.ly's features into TikTok and rebranding the app as TikTok in the U.S.

fields.summary: Twitter Limits Circulation of Unverified NY Post Story Concerning Hunter Biden in Accordance With Hacked Materials Policy
fields.details: Twitter restricted the visibility of an unverified New York Post story about Hunter Biden, citing its policy on hacked materials. The platform took this action while awaiting fact-checking of the story.

fields.summary: Telegram Utilizes Minimalist Approach to Content Moderation
fields.details: Telegram employs a minimalist approach to content moderation, where users can report content for review. According to Telegram's terms of service, users must not send spam, promote violence, or post illegal pornographic content on publicly viewable channels or bots. The platform's FAQs indicate that Telegram will remove illegal content when flagged by users. Reportable categories include child abuse, copyright violations, fake accounts, illegal drugs, personal details, pornography, violence, and spam. However, Telegram does not actively moderate content.

fields.summary: Newly Designed "Misleading Information Labels" for 2022 Elections Announced by Twitter
fields.details: Twitter announced a redesign of its misleading information labels for the 2022 elections. The update led to a 17% increase in users clicking through to read the debunking content associated with these labels. Additionally, tweets flagged with the new labels saw a decrease in engagement: 13% fewer replies, 10% fewer retweets, and 15% fewer likes.

fields.summary: Facebook Allows Trump's Calls for a Muslim Ban Despite Hate Speech Policy Violation
fields.details: Facebook allowed Donald Trump's calls for a Muslim ban to remain on the platform, even though these posts violated the company's Hate Speech policy.

fields.summary: Parler Returns Online with New Hosting and Moderation Plans
fields.details: Parler has resumed operations online, now hosted by SkySilk Cloud Services. The platform has implemented a basic content moderation system featuring a "trolling filter" that covers posts attacking individuals based on race, sex, sexual orientation, or religion. Users can still access these filtered posts by opting to click through the filter.

fields.summary: Parler Removed from Google Play, Apple App Store, and Amazon Web Services After January 6
fields.details: In the aftermath of the January 6 Capitol riot, Parler was removed from the Google Play Store, Apple App Store, and Amazon Web Services (AWS) due to its failure to moderate violent content, which posed a risk to public safety. Without a hosting platform, Parler went offline, disrupting its operations entirely.

fields.summary: Mozilla Foundation Releases Report on Platform Ad Transparency Tools, Finds All Lacking for External Researchers to Study Impact on European Elections
fields.details: The Mozilla Foundation study covers 11 platforms: AliExpress, Apple App Store, Bing, Booking.com, Alphabet’s Google Search & YouTube, LinkedIn, Meta, Pinterest, Snapchat, TikTok, X, and Zalando. The report concluded that none of these platforms provide fully functional ad repositories or the necessary tools and data for researchers and civil society groups to effectively monitor the impact of very large online platform (VLOP) advertisements on Europe’s upcoming elections.

fields.summary: Facebook Announces a Prohibition on New Ads During Last Week of Campaign
fields.details: Facebook implemented a policy preventing new political ads from being published during the final week leading up to Election Day. Existing ads could continue running, but no new political ads are allowed to launch.

fields.summary: Former Twitter Employee Turned Whistleblower Questions Twitter's Capacities to Enforce Election Policies
fields.details: The whistleblower's documents reveal issues with Twitter's handling of election integrity. The concerns raised include the platform's inadequate measures for enforcing its election policies, highlighting gaps in its ability to manage misinformation and enforce rules effectively.

fields.summary: Twitter disbands its external advisory Trust and Safety Council
Facebook Introduces New Policy Section on Inauthentic Behavior, Previously Part of Misrepresentation
fields.details: Facebook launched a dedicated policy section on Inauthentic Behavior, distinguishing it from its previous categorization under Misrepresentation. The policy defines Inauthentic Behavior as deceptive actions intended to conceal the identity of the organization behind a campaign, make it appear more popular or trustworthy than it is, or evade enforcement. This includes a prohibition on foreign government interference, specifically Coordinated Inauthentic Behavior conducted on behalf of foreign or government entities.

fields.summary: YouTube Adds 'How to Vote' Feature and Timely Election Reminders
fields.details: YouTube introduced a 'How to Vote' feature, providing authoritative information on voter registration, deadlines, ID requirements, and voting methods, such as in-person or mail-in voting. Additionally, YouTube rolled out timely reminders across its platform and social media handles in the weeks leading up to the U.S. election, offering guidance on how to register, vote, and find polling locations. YouTube collaborates with third-party data partners, like Democracy Works, to ensure accurate and non-partisan information.

fields.summary: YouTube Increases Penalty for Election Misinformation Violations
fields.details: YouTube announced an increase in penalties for violating its election misinformation policy. Channels that breach the policy will receive a "strike," and channels that accumulate three strikes within a 90-day period will be permanently removed from the platform.

fields.summary: Meta Ends Contracts for 200 Content Moderators and Lays Off 100+ in Trust and Safety
fields.details: Meta ended contracts for about 200 content moderators in early January 2023 and laid off at least 16 members of Instagram’s well-being group. Additionally, the company cut more than 100 positions related to trust, integrity, and responsibility. These staffing reductions also halted the development of a new fact-checking tool designed to allow third-party fact-checkers to add comments to questionable articles on Facebook.

fields.summary: YouTube Introduces Ad Verification and Labels for Political Ads, Showcasing Paying Entity
fields.details: YouTube introduced new ad verification processes and began requiring advertisers to confirm their identity and country of origin. Ads related to elections now display a label that indicates the entity or individual who paid for them. This measure aims to increase transparency around political advertising and improve user trust, particularly during election periods.

fields.summary: Facebook Announces Expanded Policies Against Misrepresentation Regarding Voting Procedures
fields.details: Facebook has expanded its voter suppression policies to include new measures against misrepresentations about voting procedures. Previously, the platform prohibited offers to buy or sell votes and misrepresentations about voting dates, locations, times, and qualifications. The newly added policies now also ban false claims about voting methods, such as using online apps, and statements about whether a vote will be counted.

fields.summary: Twitter Head of Trust and Safety Ella Irwin Resigns
fields.details: Ella Irwin resigned from her role as Twitter's head of trust and safety after holding the position for 7 months, following the resignation of her predecessor.

fields.summary: YouTube Rolls Out YouChoose 2020 + Voter Education PSAs via Information Panels
fields.details: YouTube launched YouChoose 2020, an interactive voting special that uses popular YouTube themes to guide viewers through the key steps of voting. These public service announcements (PSAs) are delivered through information panels, using formats like cooking tutorials comparing voting to following a recipe or auto repair videos explaining the "nuts and bolts" of voting.

fields.summary: Twitter Begins Prebunking False Information About Voting by Mail and Election Results
fields.details: Twitter introduced a "prebunking" strategy by placing information at the top of users' feeds to counter false narratives about voting by mail and election results. This initiative aimed to preemptively address misinformation before it spread widely.

fields.summary: Google Implements Limited Ad Freeze on January 6 Events and Related Topics
fields.details: Google implemented a temporary ad freeze under its 'Sensitive Events' policy, targeting ads related to the January 6 Capitol riot, election outcomes, the presidential inauguration, impeachment processes, and future protests on these topics. This policy aims to slow the spread of misinformation by preventing advertisers from running ads on these sensitive subjects.

fields.summary: Meta Exampts Threads from Regular Fact-Checking Programs
fields.details: Meta announced that Threads will follow Instagram's community guidelines but will be exempt from Meta's regular fact-checking programs. This decision eliminates a key feature of how Meta manages misinformation on its other apps. Additionally, Media Matters reports that Threads does not appear to be enforcing Meta's policies against hate speech effectively.

fields.summary: Facebook/Instagram Labels Ads with "Paid For By" Disclosures
fields.details: Facebook and Instagram now label political ads with a "Paid for by" disclosure to show who financed the ad. Additional information on the ad’s reach and audience is also provided.

fields.summary: YouTube Expands Election Ad Transparency to Include State-Level Elections
fields.details: YouTube broadened its election advertising transparency to cover U.S. state-level candidates, officeholders, ballot measures, and ads mentioning federal or state political parties. These ads are now searchable and viewable in YouTube's ad transparency tool, making it easier for users to understand political ad campaigns at the state level.

fields.summary: Twitter Lifts Ban on Former President Trump’s Account
fields.details: Twitter reinstated former President Donald Trump’s account. When questioned about the measures taken to combat misinformation ahead of the 2024 elections, and Trump’s return to the platform amid rising misinformation, Twitter responded with a poop emoji.

fields.summary: Facebook Ad Library Now Includes Targeting and Delivery Information
fields.details: Facebook updated its Ad Library to provide users with additional information about political ads, including details on targeting choices made by advertisers and how ads are delivered to different audiences.

fields.summary: Google's 2024 Election Plan Focuses on AI for Enforcement and Misinformation Control
fields.details:
Google's 2024 election plan emphasizes the use of AI both as an enforcement tool and as a potential threat in spreading misinformation. The plan includes a requirement for election advertisers to "prominently disclose when their ads include realistic synthetic content" and introduces a new requirement for creators to disclose when they have created realistic altered or synthetic content. Election-related synthetic content will also be labeled. Additionally, Google will "restrict the types of election-related queries for which Bard and the Search Generative Experience (SGE)* will return responses." Beyond AI initiatives, Google continues its voter education efforts and maintains the identity verification process for advertisers. The YouTube announcement reiterates existing disallowed content policies concerning elections, with no changes, and highlights the preferencing of information labels at the top of search results.

*Now known as "AI Overviews"

fields.summary: YouTube Strengthens Policies on Election Fraud Claims, Removing Content Posted After December 9, 2020
fields.details: YouTube announced it would remove videos promoting claims that widespread fraud or errors changed the outcome of the 2020 U.S. Presidential election. The policy applies to any content uploaded on or after December 9, 2020, following the safe harbor deadline for states to certify their election results.

fields.summary: Meta Blocks New Political Ads One Week Before 2024 Election
fields.details: Meta announced that it will again block new political, electoral, and social issue ads during the final week of the 2024 US election campaign. Ads that have previously run before this restriction period will be allowed to continue running during this time. The rationale for this restriction, as stated by Meta, remains the same as it has since 2020: in the final days of an election, there may not be enough time to contest new claims made in ads. This restriction period will lift the day after the election.

fields.summary: TikTok Adds In-App Reporting Feature for Election Misinformation
fields.details: TikTok has introduced a specific option in its in-app reporting feature for election misinformation. This new feature allows users to easily report misleading content or accounts related to elections for review, enhancing the platform's ability to manage and address such misinformation.

fields.summary: Launch of Political Campaigning Policy, establishing verification requirements for political advertisers.
fields.details: Verification requirements: "Advertisers who want to run political campaigning ads for Federal elections to self-identify and certify that they are located in the US Candidates and committees will have to provide their FEC ID, and non-FEC registered organizations and individuals will have to submit a notarized form."

fields.summary: TikTok Releases Policy on Synthetic Media
fields.details: TikTok's policy prohibits the deceptive sharing of synthetic or manipulated media likely to cause harm. Depending on the level of potential harm, the content may be labeled or removed. The platform will label such media to help users understand its authenticity and provide additional context.

fields.summary: YouTube Limits Election Ad Targeting to General Categories
fields.details: The updated election ad targeting policy limits audience targeting to general categories, specifically age, gender, and broad geographic locations, such as postal code areas. This change aims to create a more standardized approach to targeting in election ads, reducing hyper-targeted political messaging.

fields.summary: Twitter Adds Limitations on Tweets With Misleading Label
fields.details: To curb the spread of misinformation, Twitter implemented new design features that limit interactions with tweets labeled as misleading. Users must tap through a warning to view these tweets, and only the Quote Tweet option is available—likes, replies, and retweets are disabled. Additionally, these tweets will not be algorithmically recommended. The feature is targeted specifically at U.S. political figures, U.S.-based accounts with over 100,000 followers, and those with significant reach.

fields.summary: Twitter Enhances Account Security for Government Officials, Candidates, and Journalists
fields.details: Twitter introduced heightened security measures for high-profile accounts during the 2020 U.S. election. This included enabling password reset protection, implementing more sophisticated detection systems to identify suspicious activity, and encouraging two-factor authentication for accounts of government officials, candidates for office, and journalists to protect them from hacking and interference.

fields.summary: Google Blocks AI-Generated Ads Which Include Political Keywords
fields.details: Google introduced new generative AI tools for customizing ad images. As part of the rollout, the company implemented a list of political keywords that are blocked from being used as prompts to create or modify ads.

fields.summary: Twitter Expands Political Account Labeling to Include State Media Accounts
fields.details: The labeling policy now applies to key government officials, including foreign ministers, ambassadors, official spokespeople, and key diplomatic leaders. Twitter also announced that it will no longer amplify state-affiliated media accounts or their tweets through its recommendation systems.

fields.summary: YouTube Clarifies Restrictions on Election Ad Content, Prohibiting Manipulated Media and False Claims
fields.details: YouTube has clarified its ad policies to include specific restrictions on election-related content. The updated guidelines prohibit manipulated media, such as "deep fakes," and misleading claims about processes like the census. Ads or destinations making demonstrably false claims that could undermine participation or trust in the electoral or democratic process are also prohibited. The platform now provides examples to illustrate these restrictions more clearly.

fields.summary: Twitter Announces Shift to De-Amplify Content that Violates Terms
fields.details: Twitter's new enforcement philosophy focuses on de-amplifying content that violates its terms rather than removing it. The approach is described as “freedom of speech, but not freedom of reach.”

fields.summary: Former President Trump Reinstated on Meta Platforms After Two-Year Ban
fields.details: Meta announced that it had readmitted former President Donald Trump to its platforms after a two-year suspension. The decision followed a review of his ban, which was initially imposed due to the risk of further incitement of violence following the January 6 Capitol riot.

fields.summary: Twitter Introduces Candidate Account Labels for 2022 Elections
fields.details: Twitter announced the rollout of candidate account labels for the 2022 U.S. elections to prevent the spread of fake accounts. These labels are intended to help users identify authentic candidates running for office and distinguish them from impersonators or fake profiles. The labels are visible on candidate profiles and in tweets.

fields.summary: Meta Changes Political Advertising Policy to Allow Claims that the 2020 Election Was Stolen
fields.details: Meta updated its political advertising policies to allow ads that challenge the results of past elections, including the 2020 U.S. presidential election, which can now be described as "stolen" or "rigged." However, the platform still prohibits ads that question the legitimacy of upcoming or ongoing elections in countries like the U.S., Brazil, Israel, and Italy. Media outlets reported this policy change nearly a year after it was implemented, noting the quiet shift made after the 2022 midterms without public announcement.

fields.summary: X Updates Civic Integrity Policy to Address Election Misinformation
fields.details: X revised its Civic Integrity Policy to include measures for labeling or removing false or misleading information intended to undermine public confidence in an election or other civic processes. Tweets that violate these policies will have "reduced visibility" (de-amplified) and will be labeled, but not removed entirely.

fields.summary: In-App Election Guide Launches
fields.details: TikTok introduced an in-app election guide designed to provide comprehensive information about the U.S. elections. The guide offers details about federal, state, and local candidates through BallotReady, and provides voting information for every state, powered by the National Association of Secretaries of State. Additionally, it includes educational videos covering misinformation, media literacy, and the election process, created in collaboration with MediaWise. The guide is designed with user privacy in mind, requiring users to visit external websites or non-profits for actions involving personal information, such as voter registration.

fields.summary: Business Insider Reports That Twitter Has Fired 80% of Its Staff
fields.details: Twitter's workforce was reduced by 80% following Elon Musk's acquisition. In 2022, the company employed 7,800 people. Since then, 6,300 employees have been laid off.

fields.summary: Zuckerberg Denies Impact of Fake News on 2016 Election
fields.details: In 2016, Facebook and Instagram did not have specific policies addressing election-related content. Following the election, Mark Zuckerberg publicly denied claims that fake news on Facebook had any significant impact on the election results.

fields.summary: Information Panels Expanded to Address Topics Prone to Misinformation
fields.details: YouTube expanded its use of information panels to cover topics identified as prone to misinformation or conspiracy theories. When users watch videos related to these topics, the platform displays panels that link to third-party sources offering factual information. This includes well-established topics like the moon landing and QAnon, as well as specific issues such as vaccine misinformation.

fields.summary: Facebook Announces It Will Remove Misleading Synthetic Media
fields.details: acebook announced that it will remove synthetic media that is deemed misleading and likely to cause harm. This policy aims to address content that distorts reality through manipulated visuals or audio in a way that could mislead users or cause public harm.

fields.summary: Meta Tries Reducing Political Content in Users' Feeds
fields.details:
Meta announced an initial effort to reduce the amount of political content shown in users' News Feeds, with exceptions for official government agencies and authoritative health organizations like the CDC and WHO. Meta aimed to balance users' ability to find and interact with political content while tailoring the content based on user preferences. This shift invovled placing less emphasis on comments and shares when ranking political content and incorporating feedback from user surveys to adjust content visibility.

By March 14, 2024, Meta decided to stop promoting any political content in users' feeds, except for accounts that users actively follow.

fields.summary: Update to Hacked Political Materials Policy for Political Ads
fields.details:
Google updated its Hacked Political Materials policy to prohibit ads that directly facilitate or advertise access to hacked material related to political entities under its elections ads policies. Discussion of hacked materials is still allowed, but the promotion of such content through advertisements is now restricted.

Hacked material is defined as material "obtained through the unauthorized intrusion or access of a computer, computer network, or personal electronic device, even if distributed by a third party."

fields.summary: Mark Zuckerberg Announces Workforce Restructuring to Prioritize Engineering Roles
fields.details: In a letter to Meta employees, CEO Mark Zuckerberg outlined a plan to restructure the company's workforce by increasing the ratio of engineers to other roles. This shift is part of Meta’s "Year of Efficiency" initiative to streamline operations.

fields.summary: Twitter Discontinues Ad Transparency Center
fields.details: Twitter has discontinued its Ad Transparency Center (ATC), which was initially designed to provide transparency for political and issue-based ads. The decision followed the platform's prohibition of political and issue ads in November 2019 and the introduction of a Cause-Based Ad certification and review process. The ATC is no longer deemed necessary given these changes, although an archived version of the tool remains accessible.

fields.summary: YouTube Releases The 2020 U.S. Elections on YouTube: Retrospective Report
fields.details:
The goal of the report is to "provide a thorough overview of YouTube’s work to support election integrity in the 2020 U.S. presidential and congressional elections." Key components of YouTube's election integrity efforts during 2020 include guidelines under the "Spam, Decetive Practices & Scams" policies. Key areas include:

  • Voter Suppression: Content aiming to mislead voters about the time, place, means or eligibility requirements for voting.
  • Candidate Eligibility: Content that advances false claims related to the technical eligibility requirements for current political candidates and sitting elected government officials to serve in office. Eligibility requirements considered are based on applicable national law, and include age, citizenship, or vital status.
  • Incitement to interfere in democratic processes: Content encouraging others to interfere with democratic processes, such as obstructing or interrupting voting procedures.

Violating content, under the policy, would be removed with a "3 strikes you're out" rule.

fields.summary: Twitter Introduces Pre-Bunks for 2022 Elections
fields.details: Twitter announced the implementation of "pre-bunks" ahead of the 2022 elections. These prompts appear directly on users' timelines and in search results when people type terms, phrases, or hashtags associated with misinformation. The goal is to provide accurate information before users encounter potential falsehoods.

fields.summary: Twitter Adds Prompt to Encourage Users to Reconsider Sharing Misleading Information Under Civic Integrity Policy
fields.details: As part of its Civic Integrity Policy, Twitter introduced a feature prompting users to think twice before retweeting content flagged as potentially misleading. This includes a description of the Tweet or article summarizing why the content may be problematic or why the term is trending, encouraging more informed sharing decisions.

fields.summary: Twitter Bans All Political Content Ads, Including Candidates and Issue-Based Ads
fields.details: Twitter announced a ban on all political content advertisements, covering both candidate ads and issue-based ads.

fields.summary: Twitter Blue Verified Rolls Out, Leading to Public Figure Impersonations
fields.details: In November 2022, Twitter launched Twitter Blue Verified, a paid verification service that allowed users to obtain a blue checkmark, a symbol traditionally reserved for notable public figures, corporations, and influential accounts. Shortly after the rollout, numerous accounts impersonating public figures and organizations appeared, causing confusion and highlighting potential flaws in the verification process.

fields.summary: Expanding on Prior Option to Turn Off Political Ads, U.S. Users Can Now Turn Off All Social Issue, Electoral, or Political Ads
fields.details: U.S. users can now turn off all social issue, electoral, or political ads from candidates, Super PACs, or other organizations that include the “Paid for by” political disclaimer. This option builds on Facebook's previous features for ad control.

fields.summary: TikTok Adds Banners on Election Content
fields.details: TikTok introduced banners on election-related videos to direct viewers to an elections guide for up-to-date information and results.

fields.summary: Google to Halt Political Ads Across All Platforms After Polls Close on Election Day
fields.details: Google announced that it would stop running political ads across all its platforms, including YouTube, after polls close on Election Day. This decision was made to address concerns about potential misinformation in the period between the close of voting and the announcement of official results.

fields.summary: Launch of Facebook Protect to Safeguard Political Candidates' Accounts from Hacking
fields.details: Facebook introduced "Facebook Protect," a security program designed to offer enhanced protection for the accounts of political candidates, elected officials, and their teams. The program includes additional security measures, such as two-factor authentication and real-time monitoring for suspicious activity to prevent hacking.

fields.summary: Third-Party Fact-Checking Expands to Include Facebook Videos and Photos
fields.details: Facebook has expanded its third-party fact-checking program to cover videos and photos, in addition to text-based content.

fields.summary: Telegram's Ad Policy Prohibits Political Ads
fields.details: Telegram’s ad policy prohibits ads that promote political campaigns, elections, political parties, candidates, or political or religious movements. The policy also mentions that ads related to ongoing sensitive events or topics may be temporarily suspended.

fields.summary: Meta Releases Public Plan for 2024 Elections, Emphasizing Continuity with Previous Approaches
fields.details: Meta released its public-facing plan for the 2024 elections, emphasizing continuity with its approach in previous elections. The plan highlights features that encourage voter registration and the Voter Information Center. Meta states that posts rated as 'false' by third-party fact-checkers will be displayed less prominently.  In terms of political ads, Meta will not allow ads that are rated as "false, altered, partly false, or missing context."

fields.summary: TikTok Employs Standard Policy to Identify Problematic Hashtags, Block Results, and Redirect Users to Community Guidelines
fields.details: TikTok's policy, implemented during the 2020 election and continuing in future cycles, involves redirecting searches for misleading hashtags to its Community Guidelines instead of showing results. This approach aimed to combat misinformation associated with hashtags such as #sharpiegate, #stopthesteal, and #patriotparty, as well as QAnon content.

fields.summary: Facebook Labels All Posts About Voting to Point Users to Credible Resources
fields.details: Facebook began labeling posts about voting from federal officials and candidates, including presidential candidates in the U.S., to direct users to credible information sources like usa.gov/voting. These labels appear on posts regardless of their accuracy and follow an external report indicating that many top posts mentioning voting contained false or misleading information.

fields.summary: Google Lifts Temporary Ban on Political Ads
fields.details: Google announced it would lift its temporary ban on political ads, which had been imposed following the January 6, 2021, Capitol riot. This decision came as Google sought to address the concerns raised by the events of that day while reintroducing political advertising to its platform.

fields.summary: Senate Committee Letter Reveals YouTube Layoffs Resulted in Only One Global Misinformation Policy Lead Remaining on Staff
fields.details: In a letter dated June 2023, the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration reported that YouTube’s January 2023 layoffs had reduced its team responsible for global misinformation policy to just one person.

fields.summary: Launch of Top News and Breaking News features.
fields.details:
"Top News shelf prominently highlights videos from news sources in search results ... last year we saw consumption of content from authoritative news partners’ channels grow by 60%."

In the context of breaking news, video takes time to be produced. In these cases, "we've started providing short previews of text-based news articles in search results on YouTube, along with a reminder that breaking and developing news can rapidly change."

fields.summary: Twitter Changes Feed Curation to Limit Spread of Misinformation
fields.details: Twitter announced a product design change to reduce the spread of misinformation by preventing "liked by" and "followed by" recommendations from accounts the user does not follow from appearing in their timeline. The change also stopped notifications for Tweets from these accounts. This approach was abandoned in December 2020 as it hindered users from discovering new conversations and accounts to follow.

fields.summary: Facebook Amends Policy to Prohibit Posts Using Militarized Language to Intimidate Election Officials or Voters
fields.details: Facebook updated its policy to ban posts that "use militarized language or suggest that the goal is to intimidate, exert control, or display power over election officials or voters." This change was made to help prevent the spread of content that could incite violence or intimidation during elections.

fields.summary: Twitter Stops Removing Content About the "Big Steal" of the 2020 Election
fields.details: Twitter stopped the removal of posts related to the "Big Steal" conspiracy theory, citing that its Civic Integrity policy only applies during active election periods. The decision means that content falsely claiming the 2020 election was stolen will no longer be subject to removal.

fields.summary: Twitter Cuts 15% of Trust and Safety Team Days Before Election, Including Key Leader on Democracy and Civil Rights Policy
fields.details: Near the 2022 election, Twitter cut 15% of its Trust and Safety team, including Neema Singh Guliani, who led democracy, national security, and civil rights policy. Other teams critical to content moderation, such as the Product Trust team—which develops policies to prevent new features from harming users—and the Health team—which implements Trust and Safety policies—faced even heavier cuts.

fields.summary: Launch of Ad Archive in the U.S. (initially rolled out in Canada).
fields.details:
"An archive of federal-election related ads so that we can show both current and historical federal-election related ads" This feature was a compromise, noting calls to remove political ads following manipulation concerns from 2016. 

TechCrunch reported that the archive also applies to ads "dealing with political issues such as “abortion, guns, immigration or foreign policy.”"

fields.summary: Meta Lays Off Leadership and Staff of the Meta Journalism Project Amid Broader Retreat from News Engagement
fields.details: Meta has laid off the leadership and staff of the Meta Journalism Project, which has not posted any new milestones since March 2022. This move is part of a broader shift in Meta’s approach to journalism, as the company has recently terminated several news-related programs, including Instant Articles and Bulletin. Additionally, Meta has stopped paying U.S. publishers for their stories, renamed the "News Feed" to "Feed," and announced that its "Top Stories" section will soon be curated by algorithms instead of humans.

fields.summary: Google Launches Political Advertising Transparency Report
fields.details: Google introduced a Political Advertising Transparency Report, with a searchable database, providing public access to data on political ads, including information about advertisers, ad spend, and targeting strategies.

fields.summary: Twitter Permanently Suspends Accounts of Several Journalists Over Alleged Doxing of Musk
fields.details: Twitter permanently suspended the accounts of multiple journalists, including CNN’s Donie O’Sullivan, The New York Times’ Ryan Mac, The Washington Post’s Drew Harwell, and independent journalist Aaron Rupar. Twitter claimed the suspensions were due to the journalists' engagement in doxing behavior against Elon Musk. These suspensions targeted individuals who had recently been critical of Musk.

fields.summary: Twitter Releases Database of Suspected Russian and Iranian Interference in 2016 Elections
fields.details: To enable external research, Twitter released a database containing tweets and account information related to Russian and Iranian efforts suspected of interfering in the 2016 elections.

fields.summary: Facebook Rolls Out Its 'Inauthentic Behavior' Efforts
fields.details: Responding to Concerns Over Foreign Involvement in the 2016 Election, Facebook introduced its 'Inauthentic Behavior' initiative. This effort focuses on removing coordinated networks of inauthentic accounts, Pages, and Groups that attempt to manipulate public discourse. Most inauthentic accounts are related to spam or sales, and the platform typically identifies these issues based on user behavior, such as spamming, rather than content itself.

fields.summary: Twitter Begins Labeling Synthetic Media
fields.details: Twitter has introduced a labeling system for synthetic or manipulated media. Labels are applied based on three criteria: whether the media is synthetic or manipulated, whether it is shared in a deceptive manner, and whether it is likely to impact public safety or cause serious harm. On a case-by-case basis, Twitter may also reduce the tweet's visibility and/or alert users before they like or retweet the content.

fields.summary: Twitter Lifts Ban on Political Ads with Policies Varying by Country; US Prohibits Misleading Content Related to Elections
fields.details: Twitter has lifted its ban on political ads, with policies varying by country. In the U.S., the policy is permissive but prohibits false or misleading content related to elections. This includes misinformation about election participation, content intended to intimidate or dissuade voters, and information that undermines public confidence in elections. The review process for determining what constitutes "false or misleading" was not disclosed.

fields.summary: Introduction of Authorization Process for Confirming the Identity and Location of Ad Entities
fields.details: Facebook implemented a new authorization process requiring entities running ads to verify their identity and location.

fields.summary: New Spend Trackers for House and Senate Races
fields.details: Facebook introduced new ad spend trackers for U.S. House and Senate races. These trackers allow users to see how much candidates are spending on advertisements and which topics are being promoted. This feature aims to increase transparency in political advertising

fields.summary: Twitter's Former Head of Trust and Safety Describes Twitter's Trust and Safety Program Under Musk as "Nonexistent"
fields.details: Yoel Roth, Twitter's former head of trust and safety, stated that the platform's trust and safety program has become "nonexistent" under Elon Musk's leadership. He expressed concerns about the significant reduction in staff and resources dedicated to maintaining safety and enforcing policies on the platform. Roth's comments reflect broader worries about the ability of Twitter to manage harmful content and maintain user trust amidst substantial organizational changes.

fields.summary: Twitter Bars Advertising from Russia Today and Sputnik, State-Funded Media Outlets
fields.details: Twitter has prohibited advertising from Russia Today (RT) and Sputnik, both of which are state-funded media outlets associated with Russian government interests.

fields.summary: Twitter Focuses on Combatting Bots and Manipulation Networks Post-2016 Elections
fields.details: Twitter emphasized its election integrity efforts on combating automated accounts and manipulation networks. This focus is largely in response to concerns about the influence of Russian bots during the 2016 election.

fields.summary: Meta Requires AI Disclosure for Political Ads in 2024 Election Plan
fields.details: As part of their plan for the 2024 election, Meta announced that advertisers will be required to disclose when they use AI or other digital techniques to create or alter political or social issue ads in certain cases. Meta also confirmed that existing requirements for political ads will remain unchanged: advertisers must complete an authorization process, ads will include a “paid for by” disclaimer, and all ads will be included in the Ad Library.

fields.summary: Facebook Limits Circulation of Unverified NY Post Story Concerning Hunter Biden Pending Fact-Checking
fields.details: Facebook temporarily reduced the distribution of a New York Post article about Hunter Biden while it awaited verification from third-party fact-checkers. This measure was taken as part of Facebook's policy to limit the spread of potentially false information before its accuracy could be confirmed.

fields.summary: Threads to Operate on the Fediverse
fields.details: Meta announced that its Threads platform will operate on the fediverse, a collection of decentralized social media platforms that use open standards and protocols. This structure allows users to interact and communicate across multiple platforms, reducing reliance on centralized data silos, giving users the ability to host their data on their own servers.

fields.summary: Facebook Updates Voter and Census Fraud and Interference Policies
fields.details: Facebook expanded its policies to address harmful activities related to voter and census fraud and interference. The policy prohibits content that encourages or promotes illegal participation in the voting or census process, such as offers to buy or sell votes or instructions for committing voter fraud. It also covers misrepresentations regarding the dates, locations, or methods of voting or voter registration, as well as misinformation about who can vote, candidate eligibility, or participation requirements. Additionally, the policy aims to prevent content suggesting that participating in the voting or census process may lead to law enforcement consequences, such as arrest or deportation.

fields.summary: Twitter Launches 'Birdwatch' Community-Driven Content Moderation Program
fields.details: Twitter introduced 'Birdwatch,' a community-driven program that allows users to identify and annotate tweets they believe are misleading. Users can write notes providing context to misleading tweets. Initially launched as a pilot, Birdwatch (later renamed Community Notes) requires notes to be upvoted by other members before they are publicly visible. This approach aims to incorporate diverse viewpoints and provide informative context, though its effectiveness has been debated.

fields.summary: Meta Announces the Merger of its Business Integrity Unit with its Central Integrity Team
fields.details: "Meta will be held to the same standards for content moderation across both types of content ... whether ads or organic posts from everyday users." The merger of the Business Integrity Unit, which moderates ad content, with the Central Integrity Team, which moderates user posts, reflects this shift in approach.

fields.summary: TikTok Educates Paid Content Creators on Election Content
fields.details: TikTok has initiated efforts to educate content creators about the importance of proper disclosure when posting political content. The platform states that if it discovers political content was paid for and not properly disclosed, the content is promptly removed.

fields.summary: Facebook Increases Identity Verification Requirements for Political Ads
fields.details: Facebook introduced stricter requirements for political advertisers, aiming to confirm that the entity running the ad is U.S.-based. Organizations must now provide a Federal Election Commission ID, Tax-ID number, or a government website domain that ends in .gov or .mil. The goal is to help users on Facebook and Instagram better understand who is trying to influence them and why. Users can now view confirmed information about advertisers, including the type of identification provided, such as an EIN or FEC ID, allowing them to assess the legitimacy of the organization.

fields.summary: Facebook Ad Archive Replaced by Ad Library
fields.details: Facebook's Ads Archive, initially launched in May 2018 to track political and policy-related ads, was replaced by the Ad Library. The new Ad Library includes all active ads across various topics, not just political or policy ads, and also displays historical data such as page creation dates, mergers, name changes, and management locations. Users can report ads for policy violations.

fields.summary: Twitter Suspends Trump's Accounts Due to Inciting Violence in the Wake of January 6
fields.details: Twitter permanently suspended Donald Trump's accounts due to the risk of further incitement of violence following the January 6 Capitol riot. The decision was based on an assessment of Trump's tweets against the Glorification of Violence policy, which determined that his tweets violated the policy and warranted an immediate and permanent suspension.

fields.summary: Facebook Introduces Third-Party Fact-Checking Program
fields.details: Facebook launched a third-party fact-checking program to address misinformation. Community reports and other signals will direct stories to fact-checkers. If a story is deemed false, it will be marked as disputed, and users will be linked to an article explaining the fact-checking result. Disputed stories may also be demoted in the News Feed. Notably, politicians are exempt from this fact-checking process to ensure their statements remain publicly scrutinized and debated, whether made on their Page, in ads, or on their websites.

fields.summary: Meta Introduces User Controls to Opt Out of Fact-Checking Program
fields.details: Meta introduced new controls that allow users to opt out of its fact-checking program. This change permits debunked posts to appear in participants' news feeds with only a warning label, rather than being suppressed or removed.

fields.summary: TikTok Introduces Labels for Political Figures and Election Content
fields.details: TikTok implemented labels on content related to the 2022 midterm elections and on accounts belonging to governments, politicians, and political parties in the U.S in an effort to increase transparancy and help users identify political content more easily.

fields.summary: Twitter Introduces Prompt to Deter Retweeting of Misleading Information Under Civic Integrity Policy
fields.details: Under its Civic Integrity Policy, Twitter added a feature that prompts users to reconsider retweeting content labeled as misleading. Before amplifying the content, users are directed to credible information about the topic in question, encouraging more informed decision-making.

fields.summary: Twitter Announces #BeAVoter Campaign to Drive Voter Registration
fields.details: Twitter's #BeAVoter campaign aims to increase voter registration by promoting registration information and reminders. The initiative includes a custom emoji and a dedicated hashtag to encourage participation. Users in the U.S. receive prompts in their timelines with details on how to register, and the campaign highlights voter registration resources and election reminders through trending topics.

fields.summary: Labels Added to Facebook Posts Claiming Premature Electoral Victory
fields.details: Facebook and Twitter introduced a warning label for posts that claim a premature victory in the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election. The label reads: "Votes are being counted. The winner of the 2020 US Presidential Election has not been projected. See Election updates."

fields.summary: YouTube Updates Its Ads Misrepresentation Policy
fields.details: YouTube's updated policy prohibits coordinating with other sites or accounts and concealing or misrepresenting your identity or other critical details when your content relates to politics, social issues, or matters of public concern.

fields.summary: Mark Zuckerberg Defends Allowing Political Ads on Facebook, Argues Ban Would Favor Incumbents
fields.details: In defense of Facebook’s decision to allow political advertisements, CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that banning such ads would disproportionately favor incumbents and candidates who receive more media coverage. He argued that political ads provide an essential platform for candidates, particularly those with less public exposure, to communicate their messages.

fields.summary: Expansion of Fact-Checking Partnerships to Cover Election Content
fields.details: TikTok expanded its fact-checking efforts by partnering with PolitiFact and Lead Stories to address potential misinformation related to the 2020 U.S. election. These partnerships aim to ensure that false information related to the election is flagged and addressed swiftly.

fields.summary: YouTube Adds 'Voting by Mail' to the List of Sensitive Topics That Activates an Information Panel
fields.details: YouTube expanded its use of information panels by including the topic of 'voting by mail' as one that prompts a panel to appear, linking to authoritative information when discussed in videos. This change is part of YouTube’s broader effort to provide context around election-related content.

fields.summary: Twitter Launches 2020 Election Hub at Top of Explore Tab
fields.details: The Election Hub features news in both English and Spanish, presented through Twitter Moments created by reputable outlets. It includes livestreams of debates and election events, along with voter education PSAs to inform users about voting processes and key election-related information.

fields.summary: Meta Reorganizes Community Standards for Voter and Census Interference
fields.details:
Meta reorganized its community standards for voter and census interference: 1) The misrepresentation category now includes "Voter/Census Interference;" 2) The Coordinating harm category continues to include "Voter/Census Fraud."

They also include new policies under "Additional Info/Context Needed to Enforce:" 1) Coordinated Interference is content calling for interference in census or election participation; 2) Law Enforcement Consequences are claims that census or voting participation will lead to arrest, deportation, or imprisonment; and 3) Intimidation at Voting Sites are defined as statements advocating monitoring voters or officials with the intent to intimidate, using militaristic language or expressing control.

fields.summary: TikTok Releases Initial Policies for the 2024 Elections Regarding Election Centers, External Fact Checking, and Media Literacy
fields.details: TikTok released its initial policies for the 2024 elections, which primarily reiterate existing strategies: spreading trustworthy information through Election Centers, partnering with external fact-checkers, and promoting media literacy. Regarding generative AI, TikTok introduced a labeling requirement for "realistic" AI-generated content stating that it will continue developing AI detection policies to ensure responsible use.

fields.summary: Twitter Loosens Policy to Allow Trump’s “Go Back to Where You Came From” Tweet
fields.details: In a policy shift, Twitter decided to allow a tweet from former President Donald Trump telling minority members of Congress to "go back to where you came from." This decision followed internal debates and policy reviews.

fields.summary: TikTok Relaunches Elections Center with Expanded Features
fields.details: TikTok launched the Elections Center to connect users engaging with election content to authoritative information and sources in over 45 languages. The in-app center features videos encouraging critical thinking about online content and provides information about voting. For actions requiring user information, such as voter registration, users are directed to external websites like state sites or relevant non-profits

fields.summary: Parler Returns to Apple and Google Play Stores with Content Restrictions
fields.details: Parler, a social media app, was reinstated on the Apple App Store and later on Google Play Store after being removed in the wake of the January 2021 Capitol riots. The app version includes a 'trolling filter' that makes certain posts invisible on the app, though they remain visible on the web and other versions of the platform.

fields.summary: TikTok Introduces Tool for Labeling AI-Generated Content
fields.details: TikTok announced a new tool to help creators label their AI-generated content. Additionally, the platform will begin testing methods to automatically label AI-generated content.

fields.summary: Enhanced Account Security Measures for 2022 Elections
fields.details: X announced enhanced account security measures for government officials, candidates for office, and journalists ahead of the 2022 elections. This is part of the platform's effort  to safeguard the integrity of the electoral process and protect key individuals from potential security threats and misinformation. campaigns.

fields.summary: Election Explore Tab Launched by Twitter for 2022 Elections (Previously Election Hub)
fields.details: Twitter introduced the Election Explore Tab for the 2022 elections, a centralized hub for real-time political conversations, resources, and breaking news. The tab also includes public service announcements (PSAs) about voting.

fields.summary: Meta Releases Initial Papers on Facebook and Instagram's Impact on 2020 US Election
fields.details: Meta has released the first 4 of 16 papers evaluating the impact of Facebook and Instagram on political attitudes and behaviors during the 2020 US election cycle. The reports emphasize that the findings show minimal evidence that the platforms' key features cause harmful polarization or significantly affect political outcomes. Some researchers noted that the short data collection period and its timing near the election may limit the findings' broader relevance.

fields.summary: Meta Bars Use of Generative AI Tools for Political Ads in Ads Manager
fields.details: Meta announced that advertisers running campaigns for Housing, Employment, Credit, Social Issues, Elections, Politics, Health, Pharmaceuticals, or Financial Services are not permitted to use the Generative AI features in Ads Manager. In Meta's subsequent 2024 elections blog post, the company acknowledges the use of external AI tools and states that their platforms will require advertisers globally to disclose when they use AI or digital methods to create or alter a political or social issue ad in certain cases.

fields.summary: Meta Bars Political Advertisers from Using Generative AI Ads Tools
fields.details: Meta is bars political camping and advertisers from using its image-based GenAI products in an effort to curb misinformation.

fields.summary: YouTube Adds Labels for State-Funded Media Videos
fields.details: 1.5 years after YouTube's labeling policy for state-funded media outlets, a ProPublica report found inconsistent enforcement: "the world’s most popular streaming service allowed 57 channels funded by the governments of Iran, Russia, China, Turkey, and Qatar, among others, to play videos without labels."

fields.summary: President Trump Banned from Facebook and Instagram
fields.details: President Trump's initial indefinite ban from Facebook and Instagram was later amended to a two-year ban following a recommendation from the Oversight Board. The ban prohibits Trump's access to the platforms due to concerns about incitement of violence and misinformation.

fields.summary: YouTube Changes Algorithm to Prioritize Authoritative Sources in Search Results
fields.details: YouTube updated its algorithm to elevate authoritative sources for news and information queries. The platform elevates reputable news outlets like CNN, Fox News, and The Guardian in search results and "watch next" panels. For instance, when searching for major news events such as "Brexit," approximately 93% of the top results come from high-authority channels. This approach is also applied to evergreen topics susceptible to misinformation, like vaccines, where expert sources are featured prominently. YouTube continues to expand this practice to more topics and regions.

fields.summary: Candidate Verification and Account Labeling to Combat Counterfeit Accounts
fields.details: Twitter introduced candidate verification and account labeling to prevent the creation of counterfeit accounts by clearly identifying official candidates and their campaigns.

fields.summary: X Announces New Political Advertising Policy and Civil Integrity Updates
fields.details: X announced a new policy allowing political advertising, emphasizing freedom of expression and forthcoming updates to its Civil Integrity Policy. A global advertising transparency center will be created to review political posts. U.S. policies prohibit false or misleading election content, limit ads to U.S. persons/entities with pre-approval, and highlight the role of Community Notes in fostering open debate.

fields.summary: Analysis Finds Few Rigged Election Claims Labeled on Facebook and Twitter Before 2022 Election
fields.details: In the lead-up to the 2022 U.S. midterm elections, The Washington Post conducted an analysis of social media posts by candidates that claimed elections were rigged or fraudulent. The analysis found that few of these posts were labeled as misinformation on Facebook or Twitter, raising concerns about the platforms' effectiveness in addressing election-related misinformation.

fields.summary: Meta Dissolves Its Responsible Innovation Team
fields.details: Meta disbanded its Responsible Innovation Team, which comprised approximately two dozen engineers, ethicists, and other specialists. The team collaborated with internal product teams, outside privacy experts, academics, and users to identify and address potential concerns and downsides related to new products and changes to Facebook and Instagram.
